simple put its a great action film, with interesting characters and kept me intrigued and kept the action pace so I didn't get bored, id recommend it to those who like car chases, action, explosions and thrilling, exciting movies set in a fictional post apocalyptic future that's a bit mad.

Mad Max is one of the few franchises that has only improved with age, each film better than the last. There are so many awesome things from "Fury Road" to talk about, I know for a fact I won't be able to cover it all, but the short list is Furiosa Furiosa Furiosa Furiosa Furiosa, kick ass lady characters whose complexities stem beyond the act of ass-kicking, lots of disability representation, and A DUDE PLAYING A GUITAR THAT SHOOTS FIRE WHILE STRAPPED ONTO A MOVING VEHICLE. Props to George Miller for delivering my new favorite action movie and to Tom Hardy for carrying the torch of Australia's maddest antihero. This movie is SICK and if it were a person I'd high-five the hell out of it.

Begin: One of the main attractions of the movie is its collection of bizarre and deformed bodies which provide a lot of its character. The plot seems to be a weird pseudo-feminist manifesto which isn't fully fleshed out. The action is exquisite, and the acting is serviceable. Tom Hardy, however, is great as Mad Max and is probably the only person other than Mel Gibson that can play the role correctly. Recommended.
There was so much going on in the first thirty minutes of this movie it was hard to keep track of it all. But as it progresses it pulls together and becomes a great addition to the mad max saga.
Really disappointed...... miller really blew this one......
Charlize Theron was the true protagonist of the movie.  While Tom Hardening has a knack for playing brooding characters (Warrior), he was clearly eclipsed by Charlize Theron in this film.

Loved it! Was really looking forward to seeing this which is always a worry because films rarely live up to expectations but Mad Max blew them away! The plot isn't complicated, now are the characters but who cares, how many films do we watch where good films are killed by overly clever or deep plots etc. Mad Max keeps it simple, its a chase, and its all the more brilliant for it, you can just sit and take in all the madness without engaging the brain too much! It's bonkers, driving without a guy playing a flame throwing guitar on your bonnet just seems wrong now!

Probably didn't get as much out of it, as I haven't seen any other Mad Max movies, but I can say without a doubt that this is probably the best movie this year so far, only raising the bar for the other sequel movies this year (Star Wars VII, Jurassic World, etc). The action sequences were unbelievable, although the story itself was slightly lackluster. Suffice to say, this is probably the best movie you can see in theaters right now.

AMAZING direction, art design, acting, and action sequences. The story is quick and demands attention from its audience to pick up on character's motives and beliefs without an ounce of spoken exposition. It doesn't follow the stereotypical plot either with small twists here and there to keep everything fresh and exciting. The first major action sequence was so wonderfully executed, probably the only heartpounding sweat inducing action sequence I've ever seen in cinema. This begs me to ask: Why can't Hollywood produce sequels like this instead of the filth they pass off as reboots for beloved movies????

Hype. Had no expectations, went to see it because of the rave reviews. The action wasn't as non-stop and fun as some reviewers claim. Only positive I can say is your mind won't be thinking about something else while watching the movie, sometimes I guess that's what movies are for. Left the theatre feeling "Hmm...nothing great".

Beautiful, bombastic and completely insane, Mad Max Fury Road is one of those rare, special films that only comes along once in a very long while. It is one of those films that, years from now, people will ask each other if they saw it on the big screen when it came out and lament that they missed it. The term "masterpiece" gets used far too often, but I can think of no other word to accurate describe this sublime amalgamation of pulpy multiplex movie action and masterful technical film-making. From its lavish production design, to its exquisite cinematography, tight, disciplined direction, exceptional stunt and physical effects work, sharp editing, and its brilliant, booming soundtrack, Fury Road is a joy to behold for anyone who is lover of the art of film and/or a lover of action.

So far it's the best film of this year, everyone else has to beat this one. The plot is pretty straight forward, you get ejected into the story, which is amazing, no need for a long explaination, and you can still watch this without ever have watched any of the old ones. (you still should though). Oh my the characters in this are crazy and amazing. I really loved that on the one hand, this is an amazing Actionflick, and on the other hand, there are so many themes and depth to this film, I won't spoil the fun.
First and foremost I have not seen any other MM film besides the first one so I have no other film in the series to compare to.

I can't express this enough: YOU NEED TO SEE THIS MOVIE. This movie is near perfect, action packed, and just when you think it's over it starts up again. The 3D was stellar, and overall, Mad Max: Fury Road is one of the best action movies I have ever seen.

One of the best action film EVER. Its a miracle how a movies of this caliber even got made in the sea of CGI green screen action flim we see nowadays. Everything about this movie is perfect, from the acting of Tom Hardy as the enigmatic Mad Max and Charlize Theron as the badass Imperator Furiosa, the clear and concise cinematography of John Seale, majestic world design, heart-pounding score by Junkie XL... pretty much eeverything makes this the perfect action movie EVER!

Wow! What an exhilarating, crazy movie!  This is a vivid, strange, at times breathtaking action film with surprisingly strong character development and performances.  The plot is pretty straightforward but you do get involved anyways.  This over straightforwardness and relatively short length however stops this ride from being able to become the odyssey of redemption it could have been.  But it's still undoubtedly one of the most vibrant, visceral, and intense action films ever created.  You never feel like the characters are safe, which is an uncertainty lacking in almost all action films.  It's the type of cinematic experience that needs to be seen on the big screen despite its minor flaws.  This will almost certainly be the best film of the summer, and one the best of the year.

Mad Max 3 have this car chasing scene already looking bit like funny reference to MM2 but here they bring it to another level of absurd. In this movie its ONLY car chasing and entire movie look like parody with some good effects just to keep you on seat otherwise everybody would leave cinema with WTF LOL

Oh what a movie, what a lovely movie. Pretty much one of my favorite movies that have 100% action more than boring **** This movie just throws action scenes like you were a kid asking for candy. Never seen the first three Mad Max but this just convinced me into watching. By the way Furiosa is badass (;
What if the chase scene from an action movie never ended? Well, it would be Mad Max: Fury Road. That's actually the best description I can give for this move.

I went in with some higher expectations because of the critical acclaim this movie is getting.  Mad Max didn't disappoint.  For a movie with lighter dialogue and amped-up action sequences that will blow anything Michael Bay could ever hope to achieve out of the water, Mad Max has a bit of heart (though it's still somewhat light for plot and character development - only offering what you need to buy into the movie) .  It's gloriously over the top but somehow remains somewhat visceral.  The magic is happening as the result of well-crafted action sequences that progress appropriately, instead of throwing all sorts of extra obstacles and insanity "just because".  Everything is focused and paced well, and I really enjoyed that about MM.  While the first half of the movie is entertaining, it's the final half hour that really had me on the edge of my seat.  I'm not certain there's supposed to be any other Mad Max movies to follow this reboot, but they'll have to work wonders to top the action bar set here.

Wow - all those critic and user reviews were right - this really is the most amazing, authentic film to come along in years.  What a non-stop ride - the stunts were beyond impossible and were clear and visible unlike most action films with lots of cgi.  The soundtrack kept you on the edge of your seat and the visuals were wholly original and extremely gob-smacking.  I loved it from beginning to end.  This film is totally insane - you cannot keep still or quiet as the spectacle unfolds.

This film is incredible. The beautiful cinematography and visuals, the jaw-dropping practical stunts and designs that put modern CGI-filled blockbusters to shame, the fantastic performances from Charlize Theron and Nicholas Hoult (The real stars of the film; though Hardy gives a pretty good interpretation of Max), the crazy ideas and world elements that add to the post-apocalyptic chaos, the FANTASTIC action sequences that never stop or drag, the oddball humour and jokes, and the surprisingly feminist approach to gender roles within a world with no rules all add to make what is definitely the best action film in recent memory. If you haven't seen it, do. Now.

This is an action movie. That is it, nothing more and nothing less. It has no higher meaning, you get what you get, it won't make you feel any different from when you walked into the theatre. It's like going to see a glorified Michael Bay movie, albeit with better cinematography. The acclaim that this movie has received is undeserved, as it is just like any other action movie out there, it does nothing special. The times that the movie does take a turn from the two hour long car chase are pretty mediocre with unconvincing acting all around, really. Tom Hardy does a pretty okay job in this film, but he also has the same style as he does in a great majority of his work. It is a fun ride and an enjoyable watch, but not a groundbreaking development for action films.

The end action scene was fantastic right up until the 3D service. Rest of the movie is meh. Since the film looks good, would definitely recommend going to the theater to watch. Just not impressed with it as a whole.

George Miller is back! Sadly, he's just as good but not better. MAD MAX: FURY ROAD has the same exciting flow that the first two films had (let's ignore the monstrous THUNDERDOME) but the non-stop action simply does not feel new. For the first hour, I was just bored. Lulled into tedium. Then kick ass visuals jump in and Charlize Theron truly steps up. On that point, there is little Max in MAD MAX. He's barely there fading into the clutter. But what super clutter! Great to see real trucks and cars bang up without CGI. Finally, Miller is back but his new MAX is a bit of a bore. A dullard.

No spoilers in this review. Movie was great. Visual effects are awesome and the plethora of crazy cars were all uniquely bad ass. Only flaw was plot is thin. Not much to the story at all but if you love total nonstop action that wont matter.
this movie is very fun it has a lot of stunts lots of action and some funny characters.Tom Hardy does a great job playing the role of Mad Max and the girl is a complete badass

This century all movies come fullpacked with lifeless computer generated images, with a sense of unreality. That left you coming out of the cinema with a boring sensation. The movies can like more or less but you have that sensation. An emptyness sensation...

Mad Max:Fury Road is one of the best action films ever made,a pure 2-hour, relentless roller-coaster ride that never slows down,never lets action lose focus ,energy and sense of risk and danger,but most importantly,the aspect missing in big summer blockbuster movies these days,it never becomes senseless and in fact does it's best to portray unique and interesting characters in a rich,beautiful and violently insane world,that George Miller has crafted so brilliantly almost 30 years ago.

In two words:  bleak and intense.  The production value and location are astounding.  The image and sound in the new laser IMAX at The Chinese Theatre blows away for sure!  And this one at least boldly goes for the 3D to some extent, not nearly enough though, rather than cowering from it like most releases!  A simple retread story that remains effective somehow, maybe by sheer volume and spectacle done so brashly.

It's typical of action movie advertising to promise that "the thrills never stop" in a trailer with clips from the 2 or 3 best moments. Mad Max: Fury Road has the rare trailer that accurately depicts the experience that you are going to get walking into that movie theater. It's almost non-stop action with a minimalist plot.

OUTSTANDING ! Mad Max: Fury Road is an opera in four acts by George Miller, what he does in this film is pure art, there is no other way to describe. Miller gives a lesson in how to keep a movie in full motion without missing a beat or consistency. It adds up to a stranger and stunning scenery, with a distorted vision of society that goes deep into human despair; maybe a little stimulated by Miller in fact also be a doctor, something that can offer a person a more worrying vision and clarified on many aspects of life. It explores what's more sinister and ugly in human nature without being deprived by fear that can shock weaker hearts with your images. Mad Max does not want to wave it on our own. Insanity is the concept.

I think this movie was great. It was appealing visually and it was appealing in that it could tell a story through not just words but through visuals as well. This movie seem to do well in the character development department and the dialog was minimal but it complimented the films feel. Tom Hardy was a great Max and has portrayed Max in a very honest way. The only thing stopping me from giving it the full 10 out of 10 is that the film feels like it is more about Furiosa and not Max. I think the film needed a little more Max and I'm not saying that he needs more character development or he needs to talk more. I think that would have made the film worse, but I think it should have felt more like we were watching Max help Furiosa on her journey but I felt as if we were watching Furiosa's journey. However you do feel like all the action is disguising an incredibly basic and uninteresting plot and in terms of acting it's a mixed bag with some good performances and some not so good (looking at you RHW). Fans of mindless action will love this and it is impressive in so many ways, but it just doesn't have the substance to warrant me giving it any more than a (strong) 7 out of 10.

Beautiful, thrilling, suspenful, and amazing are just a few words that describe Mad Max: Fury Road. The Writer and Director of this film, George Miller was also responsible for the original Mad Max trilogy-starring actor Mel Gibson (Braveheart, The Patriot) as Max Rockatansky, who was seeking vengeance for the murder of his family. While he goes about seeking vengeance, Max (Mel Gibson) must overcome outlaws, gangs, and criminals along with his own past or ghosts rather, in a post apocalyptic setting as seen throughout all of the other films.

It's been 30 years since George Miller last showed us the insanity of his post apocalyptic Australian wasteland, with the long gap partly being due to the film's production being almost as chaotic as the world the film is set in with the film is set. It had many difficulties including being stuck in development hell for years, filming being repeatedly delayed, and difficulties in securing locations to shoot the film. Miller had plans to do the film as far back as 2003 with Gibson intended to reprise his role but took a further 10 years before tuition. But fortunately Miller persevered through all this turmoil to once again to return to the driver's seat of the franchise and create this masterpiece that is his best film yet.
The most important action movie of at least the last ten years, if not the last 15. First, let's cover some basic complaints:

Mad Max is an astoundingly good action movie in and of itself, and the fact that it passes the Bechdel test over and over is a fantastic bonus.  I hope this movie goes a long way to showing that the reason fewer action movie-goers are women isn't that we don't like explosions and car chases, it's that a lot of us like a plot we can be interested and invested in to hold the action scenes together.  Really, I think that's the magic of Mad Max--it has a story that automatically piques my interest and sympathy by presenting a group of people attempting to escape a system that has brutally taken advantage of them their entire lives.

One of the greatest pieces of visual story-telling I've ever seen. A world is extremely effectively presented and described with such a small amount of dialogue I was shocked when at the end it wasn't one-liners or conversations that resonated with me, but the set pieces and sequences that themselves described the personalities and motives of each interesting character. A full balls-to-the-wall unforgiving action adventure ride that made me question if 2 hours had truly passed since I sat down to watch the movie.
People these days waste too much time over-analyzing every movie, song or novel as if they were homework assignments meant to be broken down and explored exhaustively.

One of those rare post apocalyptic movies that isn't so depressing it makes you contemplate suicide; that isn't unrealistically upbeat; that isn't based on zombies, not saying I don't like zombie stuff; that creates a fictional culture that is believable, not a derivative of current deviant popular culture; that can actually tell a story without Morgan Freemen narrating; that doesn't tell you everything so your imagination can fill in the blanks; that doesn't suck like 98% of the junk Hollywood puts out these days.
Haven't seen the others but this sparked my interest for the franchise. Hugely entertaining and very action-packed. This could be a great representation of the series.

MM:FR works much better as a series of truly impressive set pieces than as a movie.  I felt beaten and exhausted (as George Miller may have intended) well before the end.  And I could not turn off my mind; too much disbelief, not enough suspension.  Has any other film had as great a difference between the male and female characters?  The very intense and busy action sequences were easy to follow, not confusing blurs as so many are these days, and the human (collateral?) damage was not overdone (no slow motion with torrents of blood).  The trailers do prepare you for MM:FR, except for the subjective length of this very long 2 hour movie.
best action movie of all time!

Oh **** Mad Max: Fury Road. That’s a good place to end, but no, just like George Miller we are plowing through to the bitter end. I watched somebody watch this on the little screen they stick on the back of airplane seats for long, cheap international flights. What the hell? Are you reliving the storyline so you can untangle some of the more complicated plot points (oh, that scene had 37 explosions, 2 were very subtle)? Are you soaking in all that rich character development (yes there is some, but stop acting like that’s revolutionary just because it’s better than would have been bad)? Did you accidentally see Confessions of a Shopaholic and just immediately need to burn the experience out of your veins? No, fellow traveler, you probably just love it so much that you would watch it on a **** if Apple would only let you, basking in the memory of all that blistering sight and sound while squinting against the glare on the morning train. I grew up with Mad Max. I wore out my bootleg Road Warrior tape when I got chicken pox. This is a different Mad Max in nearly every way, but it’s also a better one. I take it as a reboot. That makes things cleaner. There is maybe a 5% chance a sequel will be half as good or more than this new original—so revel in it while you can. And if you meet someone who doesn’t like it, don’t get on their case. They are weak, they have a condition, they don’t have the constitution for your impression of a War Rig.
I don't like this movie that much, but you'll possibly give it an 8 or higher. Mad Max: Fury Road is another decent adventure from the franchise. I would give this a 6 if I wanted to, but nope.

Mad Max: Fury Road" is not a classical masterpiece like "The Godfather" or "Gone with the Wind".  Yet, It is an artistic masterpiece, as well as a wonderful, cinematic achievement.  George Miller's direction is about as good as it can possibly get.  It seems as if every idea that entered Miller's mind, over the last 30 years, was included in "..Fury Road".  Amazingly, it all worked!  9.5 out of 10.

Admittedly late to the game here, but I honestly can't see where all these 10s and 100s come from.  At 70, I guess George had one more Mad Max episode left in home, but  this was nothing more than a an utterly incomprehensible wild romp.  Fury Road is nothing more than a video game brought to the screen with its threadbare plot, not to mention clothing on our five fetching damsels in distress, on which the plot loosely hinges like their chastity belts.  What little story there is might be seen as poetic in a post-apocalyptic sort of way.  I have to hand it to Charlize Theron for trying to rise above the horribly malevolent nature of this film and give us some sense of hope in the arid violent future George Miller imagines.  However, even she couldn't save this film from itself.  There were some moments of dark humor, such as the aging biker chic gang, the last to hold onto the seeds of a Utopian dreamworld.  The only suspense was whether this green world still existed, but apparently the only thing left was one desolate tree that didn't look strong enough to pull a dune buggy much less a war rig out of the quagmire.  I guess it had very deep roots.  It's just an inglorious ride through the Australian outback with some wild-eyed visual effects along the way, as if George has been dabbling in magic mushrooms.  It's fun to a point, but the sad part is you really don't care what happens to anyone in this movie.

What the hell did I just see? This is a film about a bunch of completely insane loonies on a road trip from hell, through a post-apocalyptic waste-land, to save a bunch of people from a totally nuts scary looking boss dude who drips feeds water to the rest of the population. They even have a crazy guy playing a crazy guitar with fire shooting out the neck of the guitar, on a truck. It was very AC/DC. But aside from all this, this film moves at break-neck speed. It has some of the best stunts (if not THE best) ever performed for the screen. It has a good plot, and acting. But most importantly, it has a VISION. And that is what I think makes it great. George Miller is a master of filming action. It shows in every scene. This film is more like a ride than a film.
This movie was a spectacle... a top notch spectacle. Every shot was a painting. Every concept was over the top. Every scene was a 20 minute non-stop buzz saw of guzzoline-filled action.

Mad Max Fury Road is directed by George Miller starring Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron, and Nicholas Hoult and is a continuation to the Mad Max series making this the 4th film. Ladies, Gentlemen, Mad Max Fury Road, was Mind-Blowing. I haven't seen such amazing action sequences in a movie since movies like the Indiana Jones Trilogy, Aliens, Die Hard, Terminator 1 and 2, Kill Bill Vol.1 and 2, and the Matrix! This movies action is unbelievably revolutionary and original that it will make you so pumped to see the movie again and again. Now what makes this movie feel so unique, and so action packed, is its beautiful shots and smooth paced action shots. The big plus is that most of the action in this film is made by practical effects! Lately we have been watching lots of movies with unbelievable amounts of CGI, which is not a bad thing in some ways. I enjoy CGI once and a while it can sometimes be amazing and sometimes terrible. I recently saw Avengers 2 which was full of CGI and I hugely enjoyed the film. But the practical effects in this film were by far better than any of the CGI effects ever released out in the Cinematic Universe!

To all those who complain about the story being incoherent because it solely is 2 hours of chasing, I want to say that you are conventional as hell, and that is a big flaw to me. This film is lost in its own little world, I love this f**king movie.

Great movie, but I don't think it's as "groundbreaking" as many people are making it out to be. Sure, the action is breathlessly rousing and the imagery is quite beautiful, and there's a lot of narrative thrills to be had, but I think they should have fleshed out some characters further. Characters like Furiosa. Her past is questionably underdeveloped and that bugged me a little bit. Not the best movie of 2015, but surely a great one. I'm not a fan of the "Mad Max" franchise (the first movie didn't do much for me to elevate my excitement), but this was a nice film with some fun action and nice performances.

If you haven't seen this movie than you are missing out. Mostly every character is flushed out and the action doesn't slow the movie down. The movie does take it's time to really get into the story, and that's a good thing. It introduces us to the world and characters Max will be interacting with. Furiosa is a very well rounded character and isn't just put in there to make the feminist crowed happy. George Miller wanted to create a believable character that happened to be a woman, not the other way around. She was defiantly treated as a person first and a woman second. The only complaint I have for the movie is that I would have liked for the main villain to have been more flushed out, but he isn't as bad as some movie villains these days. Everyone had a reason for being there, and the story works well because of it. All and all, Mad Max: Fury Road, will leave you satisfied while wanting more. 9/10.

As I was despairing at Hollywood inability (or unwillingness) to make good movies, along comes this masterpiece taking us to this post-apocalyptic world returned to barbarism. The genius of this movie is that it doesn't explain things with monotonous contrived dialog, it shows us with exquisite carnage! And with 'action' and few words it manages to show us a completely fleshed out, deep and believable world. If fiction requires the suspension of disbelief on the part of the viewer, then it has failed... it is fiction's job to take us there, and this does, making the insane seem perfectly sensible.

It’s been thirty years since Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome hit the cinemas bearing almost no resemblance whatsoever with 1979’s Mad Max and its sequel in 1981, The Road Warrior. The original Mad Max was uniquely odd and the second film, if memory serves correctly, was exciting if a tad more conventional. Beyond Thunderdome was just a disaster. A copper bottomed clinker that had Tina Turner appear for novelty value in addition to a load of dishevelled snotty nosed brats. This combination ensured thatt the turn off was complete. Thankfully, Fury Road is considerably better than that debacle, but is some way behind the earlier two instalments and is certainly not worthy of the euphoric reviews and praise that have been heaped upon it by both the critics and public, singing in unison for once it would appear. Production values are sound and it must be said that visually the film is an absolute delight. John Seale’s cinematic compositions for day and night are constantly impressive and there is one corker of a moment when what looks like a sand dune suddenly metamorphosis’s into Max (Tom Hardy). There is also much stylisation in the battle scenes with jump cuts adding immeasurably to the impact and editing that moves along at the rate of knots. The sound is another strong plus and whilst there is plenty of appropriate menace in the score one is unprepared for just how beautiful the music is here.

Fury Road is the pinnacle of action films. It perfects the art, and delivers two hours of nonstop action, whilst still conveying a captivating story and fitting in both strong male and female roles without fuss or attention drawn to any of these facts. It's just there for the audience to witness. The old technique of 'show, don't tell' is thought of brilliantly in the film. Every frame can tell a different story of the world beyond what we already know. There's no way to praise this film enough: George Miller managed to create a masterpiece here.

I'm quoting a friend, but Mad Max Fury Road is like drinking a Monster energy drink and chasing it with a Red Bull.  This movie is non-stop action.  I went in with rather low expectations and was blown away.  From the beginning of the movie, all the way through to the end is one huge, awesome, car chase.  The onesie pajama-wearing, flamethrower guitar playing guy on the mobile speaker semi with drummers on back was genius.  This has to be the best movie I have seen this year.
Is it an LA freeway or an apocalyptic nightmare or just miles and miles of high octane road rage?

No plot, not one character to care about, I just hoped they'd all die so the film would end. Boring as hell. People who like this must have drunk too much **** milk. Terrible garbage anyone could write better.

I must have seen a totally different movie than the rest of the critics and reviewers. This was a movie full of cars, gun-fights, and explosions that somehow manages to be boring. The script feels like the first draft for an undergraduate screenwriting class, with Max uttering little more than a few grunts throughout the full two hours, a plan that flies in the face of all the rules for the universe that have already been set, and religious zealots who turn to celebrate the people who killed their messiah. Throw in some sloppy editing and bad pacing and this was ultimately a forgettable film.

This film was so much more than I anticipated. Let's start with the action scenes which delivered on all fronts. They were full of art and simply fun to behold. Mad Max had so many social layers that I didn't see coming and I enjoyed. The story moved seamlessly from character introduction and development, to plot and scenery. There wasn't a single weak link in the bunch here, every single actor pulled their weight and drew you into this apocalyptic world. Well done.

okay i`m over 50 may be this movie is for the young people. if it was not for the special effects in the movie it would have been very boring.  it was not one of best movie of the year by a long shot but is also was not the worst movie of the year. but i will not see any more of mad max if they make more..  so yea you will need the big screen for the special effects that's it.  but really i would wait for the rental if you want to save your money.
I wanted to pull out my eyes at the movie theather... that bad....

Yeah its been overpraised, but you know, its hard to call this film anything other than a success in terms of what it wants to do. Its made to show just how to do it in terms of practical bombastic effects, and that CGI should be used to add to already great stunts instead of BEING the stunts in themselves. You will be hard pressed not to say 'awesome silliness' when the guitar guy shows up for the first time. If you like action, have a thing for vehicular mayhem, and enjoy the fallout/rage/borderlands wasteland settings, this is for you.

Miller gives us a crazy take on the post-apocalyptic world. His vision is twisted, violent, and at times quite humorous. It's a very stylistic film. Unfortunately I couldn't find too much substance backing it up.

If you want to see something revolutionary and utterly mad, watch Mad Max: Fury Road. This film oozes suspense, tension, action, insanity and at-the-edge-of-your-seat entertainment. The genius mind behind this film, i.e. George Miller's, is one I am endlessly thankful for; finding a man with an imagination like his is one in a million. Tom Hardy and Charlize Theoron put on strong performances however, Nicholas Hoult takes the cake for best performance in my opinion. Every single second in this film is gripping. Mad Max: Fury Road is anything but a disappointment.

Thanks to the creative and visionary director, Mr. Miller, vfx team for ground-breaking visuals, the production designer Colin Gibson (and the whole art department) and most of all, thanks to the hero of the film (in my opinion) the cinematographer John Seale.They raised the bar and carry science fiction filmmaking to another level.

If you enjoy movies that have a long winded explanation for every single little detail narrated by the soothing voice of Morgan Freeman, you will hate this movie. On the other hand, if you like good ol' fashioned action and crazy characters doing crazy stunts, you'll love it. This is a GREAT action movie. This is the best action flick I've seen in a decade or more. Miller does not beat around the bush and tries to show not tell as much as possible. There are some pauses in the action, however they are also brief and to the point. The characters say what they need to say and then it's time to move on. There is no plot? I'm not saying it's some revolutionary story here, but the plot is at least as good if not better than the previous Mad Max movies. This is not drama, this is action at it's finest. The visuals are stunning and the stunts are all choreographed without CGI. This is a movie that will stand the test of time and become a classic just like Road Warrior.

This is one of the worse movies I've seen in my lifetime (52 yrs.).  It is all the worse because I consider the first two films in the installment classics; especially Road Warrior.  These films had a visceral emotion that, in retrospect, I had no right to expect from anything made with today's technology.  What is strikingly shocking is that this film does offer some "real" stunts...but they're worthless unless you appreciate them in a vacuum.  The movie is a complete mess: Max is a eunuch, unable to muster even a single moment of greatness, a single line of dialogue worth remembering, or even a reason to pull for him.  The rest of the characters are completely lacking of development; and women are either used and abused, or superheroes (how, we don't know) that have survived in the wasteland...waiting for what?  Charize to come along and lead them?  It's absolute garbage, that leads to nowhere..over and over again.  Watch a real movie: Road Warrior, The Good the Bad and The Ugly; hell, watch El Mariachi (I'm serious)....and have fun with two+hours of your life.

In the directors cut for Aliens, James Cameron introduces the film as "40 miles of bad road". In Mad Max: Fury Road the road is 40 miles (not precisely) of explosive, high adrenaline, gloriously violent comic book action & adventure. The film wheel-spins of the start line and the furious pacing never lets up. The dialogue is sparse, the story straightforward, but its through what is essentially one big action set-piece that this film drags you along relentlessly. The visuals and stunt work are truly superb. If you are looking for a balls-to-the-wall action film that delivers, Fury Road is the flick for you.

This is it. This is truly the greatest movie of all time. I wish I was joking, that this "silly" action movie full of explosions, this two-hour car chase, this movie so ripe with violent hyperbole and rusted metal, is somehow the greatest movie ever made, but it is. It may not have the most thought provoking plot, the most mind bending twists, or the most intricately crafted story. However, when you go to see a movie, you come in with some expectation of what you are about to see. I didn't expect that with this movie. This movie showed me something different, that there is a different way. There is a different way to make movies where artistry and orchestration of a million tons of steel and a trillion tons of sand can combine to tell a story on its own. Where absolutely no camera shots or words are wasted. Where every single frame plays together to create a masterpiece of visual and active story telling. Where every second of dead air hangs thick with anticipation. This movie is a circus; George Miller is laughing as he takes apart expectation and he shreds action movie tropes, only to have something truly original and important come out the other side. The most original, daring, and inventive movie in 30 years is an installment in a 30-year-old franchise. That is the cosmic irony and beautiful existence of Mad Max: Fury Road. I can not comprehend a better movie than this. It is exactly what I have always wanted.

When you consider that this is a franchise that has lain dormant for thirty years, the director is 70 years old and the original star is nowhere to be seen you would be forgiven for fearing the worst. What you won't expect is just what a balls to the wall, non stop action packed thrill ride this has turned out to be. Short on plot and dialogue, Fury Road relies on all out action that barely lets up, physical effects that make most CGI in films look redundant and an abundance of imagination that could populate three films rather than just this one. A triumph on all levels. Michael Bay - look and learn!!

Mad Max: Fury Road is an insane waste of money, focusing in the technical aspects of a film, just for Hollywood to like, but as empty as the minds of people who liked it. The scenario is set mysteriously with the protagonist hunted by his past, making the movie very promising, when he arrives to the city it’s presented the context of this post-apocalyptic world ruled by a tyrant; however when they get to the road the whole thing falls apart. The plot is meaningless, simple and at one point becomes incoherent; the worst thing is that George Miller tries to hide it with an opulent artillery of explosions. It’s true that action cinema is all about that, but what makes an action movie stand out from the rest is the thing that sustains the significance of the explosions and fights. Mad Max is indisputably a technical achievement, highlighting the make-up; this and Charlize Theron are definitely the only good items in the feature.

Fury Road is in general an improvement, but when you get down to it, the cars do most of the acting.
